reporting-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

description.narrative: Detailed description of the activity. hrough this activity, the Georgian NGO Civic IDEA intends to identify and train a new generation of “democracy champions” from throughout Georgia – young people who are leaders/influencers in their communities but who have not yet been engaged with national civil society and media. Using computer technologies, Civic IDEA will develop a study program for the Virtual Academy for Democracy, which 260 young participants will follow on-line for 10 weeks (in several small groups throughout one year) thus both obtaining knowledge they need to remain democracy activists, but also networking with their like-minded peers and meeting well-established Georgian experts. As a result of this component, young people with a potential of bringing positive changes will be equipped with academic information, practical skills and networks for further growth (in as far as this is achievable in 10 weeks). Civic IDEA sees this as an investment into Georgia’s democratic and pro-European future. In parallel to this on-line program, experts from this organization will offer “live” training in hose towns which they will be visiting while promoting the Virtual Academy for Democracy. Here, 240 interested people – first come-first service basis, no selection criteria – will attend 4-5-day trainings on various topics related to democracy-building. While the organization admits that all the 500 people that it will reach out to in the framework of this project will not necessarily remain/become activists, it still sees this Democracy network as an important step in empowering grassroot people and giving them tools for raising their voices and getting themselves heard. The most active participants will remain involved with the organization and will be further helped by Civic IDEA experts to do common projects and get access to other relevant civil society initiatives. A significant added value of the project is the team behind it – founders and board members of Civic IDEA are well-known public figures who have been politicians, top civils servants and activists of a high caliber. It is this background against which the Embassy has weighted the chances of success of this activity as well as its sustainability. On sustainability: having created educational resources, Civic IDEA will make them publicly available and will continue fund-raising for recruiting more participants into the program in coming years. In that sense, the project is quite reminiscent of other short-term education initiatives, including those supported by the Embassy, such as Tbilisi School of Political Studies and EECMD’s Democracy Schools. At the same time, the organization intends to promote the curriculum of the Virtual Democracy Academy among universities to turn it into an optional course. The Embassy will be partnering up with Civic IDEA for the first time via this project and this bears a certain risk for us in terms of efficiency and administrative reliability of this organization. If successful, this can be regarded as a pilot project and be continued into another year.
